meanings.def: to break something suddenly with a sharp noise; to be broken in this way
examples: snap something The wind had snapped the tree in two.
snap something off (something) He snapped a twig off a bush.
snap (off) Suddenly, the rope snapped.
The branch she was standing on must have snapped off.
One of the table's legs had been snapped off.
She picked up the pencil and snapped it in two.

meanings.def: to take a photograph
examples: snap something A passing tourist snapped the incident.
snap (away) She seemed oblivious to the crowds of photographers snapping away.

meanings.def: to move, or to move something, into a particular position quickly, especially with a sudden sharp noise
examples: + adj. The lid snapped shut.
His eyes snapped open.
+ adv./prep. He snapped to attention and saluted.
The plastic pieces snap together to make a replica of a dinosaur.
snap something + adj. She snapped the bag shut.

meanings.def: to speak or say something in an impatient, usually angry, voice
examples: + speech ‘Don't just stand there,’ she snapped.
snap (at somebody) I was tempted to snap back angrily at him.
snap something He snapped a reply.
‘How should I know?’ Jen snapped back.
He lost his temper and snapped irritably at the children.

meanings.def: to try to bite somebody/something
examples: The dogs snarled and snapped at our heels.

meanings.def: to suddenly be unable to control your feelings any longer because the situation has become too difficult
examples: My patience finally snapped.
When he said that, something snapped inside her.
And that did it. I snapped.
I guess he just snapped.

meanings.def: to fasten a piece of clothing with a snap
to start play by passing the ball back between your legs
examples: Time will not be resumed until the ball is snapped on the next play.

meanings.def: to shout at somebody in an angry way, especially without reason
to make a sharp noise by moving your second or third finger quickly against your thumb, to attract somebody’s attention, or to mark the beat of music, for example
examples: He snapped his fingers for the waiter to bring more wine.
He snapped his fingers and the waiter came running.

meanings.def: to make an effort to stop feeling unhappy or depressed; to help somebody to stop feeling unhappy
examples: You've been depressed for weeks. It's time you snapped out of it.

meanings.def: used, especially in orders, to tell somebody to start working harder or more quickly

idioms.def: to shout at somebody in an angry way, especially without reason
to make a sharp noise by moving your second or third finger quickly against your thumb, to attract somebody’s attention, or to mark the beat of music, for example
examples: He snapped his fingers for the waiter to bring more wine.
He snapped his fingers and the waiter came running.

idioms.idiom: snap out of it/something | snap somebody out of it/something
idioms.def: to make an effort to stop feeling unhappy or depressed; to help somebody to stop feeling unhappy
examples: You've been depressed for weeks. It's time you snapped out of it.

idioms.def: used, especially in orders, to tell somebody to start working harder or more quickly

meanings.def: a sudden sharp noise, especially one made by something closing or breaking
examples: She closed her purse with a snap.
the snap of a twig

meanings.def: a photograph, especially one taken quickly
examples: holiday snaps
I managed to get a snap of the incident.
She took a snap of all the hotels we stayed in.

meanings.def: a card game in which players take turns to put cards down and try to be the first to call out ‘snap’ when two similar cards are put down together
a type of button used for fastening clothes, consisting of two metal or plastic sections that can be pressed together
to be very easy to do
examples: This job's a snap.

idioms.def: to be very easy to do
examples: This job's a snap.

meanings.def: made or done quickly and without careful thought or preparation
examples: It was a snap decision.
They held a snap election.

meanings.def: you say snap! in the card game called ‘Snap’ when two cards that are the same are put down
people say snap! to show that they are surprised when two things are the same
examples: Snap! I've just bought curtains exactly like those.
